titleStmt.title: Huon d'Auvergne, Bibliteca del seminario vescovile MS 32 (P), Annotations

div.note: Also transcribed by Holtus (2001), pp. 48-50, lines 1-109; Pasinus, 1-10; Peyron 1-16; Graf (1878) 1-72.

Rajna here places a description of the miniature: Min. 1. un re (tutto army) e parecchie altre figure; non intendo bene l'imagin/ Yug. dirige un psonag/ porge un breve/ ad un altro ch 'è/ inginocchiato/ forse l'invito d'uon a corte
Numbers in Rajna's notebook are in pencil, added later.
Rajna: 2r. The manuscript began on a recto when he saw it, with 6 lines: 4 followed by a miniature, with two more following it. Here is the beginning of today's MS.
In Rajna's transcription, "y." somewhat after "el" above the line.
Rajna notes "sic" after vevole.
Holtus: los. "y" crossed out; Rajna: "caratt. più picc / forte aggiunte fatte / poi –i =" (marginal note).
Rajna, note in right margin (sic). B: Anchois le haete la giant d[e] la [con]trie. T seems to be missing the verb, "odia"; an emeded reading might be anzo li (odi)a la zente de la contrà.
Rajna note: "prima soa e così / parrebbe ancora / non credo si [tr?] /volz corregg".
Rajna reverses these two lines, and uses numbering in the left margin to make clear their order.
Cf. Crusca, al dilungo, vol. 1.
Rajna, note "no del solito inchiostro / più nero delle giunte." At the beginning of his transcription, Rajna comments more on the various details of handwriting than toward the end.
Rajna: seneschalcho, with the first "e" changed into "i" with a dot above and filled in.
End of Holtus (2001) transcription.
Rajna's notebook has "V" in the left margin, together with a crossed-out label, "IV."
Rajna omits this line and later inserts in the right margin, thus beginning the line numbers of his transcription being off from the total.

Rajna: messy note here, running over beginning of the following line: "O e in? / (non) mi pare" after having crossed out "Em?"; the "non" is written after, squeezed in; he clearly was not sure. The "E" covers the beginning of "Charlo" below.
This line omitted in Rajna initially, inserted in right margin according to signal similar to "F." MS: ācorte, at the beginning of the line.

prendea: the "e" is not clearly formed, missing the loop. However, here as elsewhere, if there is not a dot for the "i" I presume that it is an "e": thanks to M. Scattolini for this tip. In the right margin, Rajna has added a note, "I vari aggiunti nei margini sono stati saltati nella trascrizione frettolosa." Perhaps this explains the problem with this line: the king should have taken him by the hand, "prenduto" or something similar, and instead there are two verbs, "avè" and "prendea."

Rajna: zos, with a mark in the margin; note on left side, referring to that mark: "qui un (a) lett. cancellz/ e sopra scritto un e, a.i./ Si dice legittima, legg. zosa." He has an "a" crossed out in the right margin.
MS: baldovĩo; Rajna: baldovij, with a note in the left margin, "corr. in baldovĩo a.i."

It is difficult to make sense of this line; I'm interpreting "each of them knocked his own down thoroughly," which requires understanding "le sovo" for MS: le sono (the parenthesis are for the emendation). However "n" and "v" are frequently difficult to distinguish; cf. Holtus 1985, p. XXXV.
Rajna initially misses this line and inserts it afterward in the margin.

There are a couple of ways that this could be interpreted: first, "le roi... / armé, et avec toutes ses armes décorées d'une fleur de lys"; or, "[the king] is armed in weapons all decorated with a fleur-de-lys"; that is, the second word of the line could be a verb or the conjunction.

elziso: this form seems to be from alzire/elzire; cf. Aquilon de Bavière, "to kill"; the line then means, "that is, Huon, who wouldn't have killed him [Berardo] at all." Compare to B, where the verb is "to hate."
This line does not make sense, since the copyist didn't understand the type of horse, "amoravis" and changed the term to something he knew! Compare with B.
Rajna's copy shows a spot above "quelo," but it does not seem to be a dot to an "i" merely an imperfection in the paper.

Illumination follows: Rajna, "2 giostra." In fact there is a view of one horsed man from the front, with a crown on his head and a sun on his chest in the center of the page; behind, to the right, there is a side view of a figure in grey on horseback with his lance at the attack position, with the same sun motif on the horse's caparison and a cape visible on his back.
Rajna initially omits this line and adds it in the margin afterwards.
B: selong lor coi[n]tenance. Nowhere else in this MS does any such form "sealonga" appear.
Rajna initially skips this line and adds it later in the left margin.
Rajna note: "li lom o loim, non /loin; ma / il segno sopra non / è un i troppo/ legittimo, ma rro/ poi (mi pare) un segno / p l'asta sotta / posta – se è / fu mal fatto."
Rajna, note in margin: (sir, voglio)
"a dove a dove"= a due a due; cf. "sove" = sue
This line and the following are initially incorrectly ordered in Rajna, who then writes numbers in the left margin to indicate the correct order.
sorprisse: there is a dot above the second "r," not above the following vowel.
Rajna notes that he is not sure whether the MS reads "in" or "m." The strokes are linked.
Illumination: two men under tree, one with horns and bells, the other with hat over his eyes.
The MS has been scratched: ve:y is what the MS looks like. B: Quant vos forma (l. 421)
Rajna has a mark after "chy" and before "ßve" that is unclear; it looks like a little caret. Perhaps this should read "ss[er]ve"?
Rajna omits the "o" of "yo."
There seems to be a line missing here; cf. B 444: Non ai ge soingn fors tout soul de celli (between this line and the following).
Rajna omits the "u" of "nuy." These two omissions make one wonder about the "y" in line 444—should it be "yo"?
MS: chre da more in B reads qui n'iert d'amore
Rajna transcribes in reverse order this and the following line; he numbers in left margin to indicate the need to reorder.
Rajna: ne piga. He underlines the word and has a line under the "p"; would seem to have been uncertain himself of the reading. B: emplie.
Cf. Dante and the pilgrim's expressions of shame: e.g., Inf. 17.85-90.
For "se tene y[n]tra ello" B: si tient traïe
After the second "pensery," Rajna notes (sic).
Rajna: anyda parla
Rajna initially omits this line, then inserts it in the left margin.
Rajna has a number of marks above this line that appear to be abbreviations: "razŷ...tōrmenta."
Rajna initially omits this line, then inserts it in the left margin.
B 549: Ja estes sire, et tot a vos atent
The second half of this line is problematic; the hemistich reads in B: "Oïl, mon bon segnor."

savye: where the ink is worn, it is frequently difficult to see the tail below the line; this could well read savie. However, under the light the tail can be seen. Here the tail is only visible with the ultraviolet light.
Rajna reverses this line and the following, noting the correct order in the left margin.
Rajna reads "guer" but the MS clearly reads a sapiate just at the edge of the burned portion.
Rajna reads "guer" but the MS clearly reads a sapiate just at the edge of the burned portion.
Illumination follows (Rajna: "4 Fig (Carlo e Sandino)
Rajna, marginal note: "e dei corr. Sng."; this last must be an abbreviation.
"Si non, défiez le..." (Literally, "Cela si il se trouve [si il est] que non)"
Rajna omits initially and then inserts in the left margin.
Rajna reverses this line and the following, and indicates the correct order by numbering in the left margin.

End of the first fascicle of Rajna's notebook. Second begins with next line, "Tor. 2." in upper corner, with "13" in red underneath. From here on, there are only numbers in red in the upper right corner of each opening, not sequential numbers as in the first fascicle.

viva: these last four letters are distinctly different from the other strokes around them. They are smaller, and written above the bottom line of the rest of the verse. Added afterwards, with a different pen? Perhaps originally the end read "li à"?
Before "aƣpir" there is a little stroke above the line. However, since there is no caret or other mark to indicate insertion, I do not include it in the text. Rajna: apreso; MS clear has "apresso."

Illumination follows this line. Huon is kneeling before a double-crowned figure on a what seems to be a tiled floor (alternating dark and light), looking at a book that figure is holding open. Other figures are visible to the right, and one stands on the side of Huon, a little to our left looking at a book. Rajna leaves a bit of a blank but does not summarize the illumination as he does for later folios.

See B 804-805: "Sens, abstinance, proece, tot ingual / In vos habite et ont pris son hostal." The Turin version is missing a line, "Intelligence, abstinence, ability, all equally..." or something similar, before this line.
Rajna reverses this and the next line, and numbers in the left margin to indicate the correct order.
pi(ù): blot on page at this point: cannot read the letter underneath
Scattolini notes that vv. 820-821 are reversed in order in comparison with B, creating difficulties in meaning.
Rajna notes "altro inch[iostro]/.d. /e mano"; the remaining MS text does not show notable differences, so he must be referring to the initial. The reference for the ".d." is unclear.
Rajna initially omits this line, then inserts it in the left margin.
The capital is like a "G" in capital form in Rajna.

Rajna has a large ink blot at the beginning of (his) 845-46 that blocks part of the reading, and at the end of his 846, has some difficulties: unclear if "fassemo" and then corrects to "demora" (the "o" has been changed and reinforced).
MS: "t(r) a" crossed out after zuro
Before che: crossed out word
ell'era = "ello era"
Rajna omits this line initially and inserts it later in the right margin.

Illumination follows this line. Much of the color is gone: to the far right a ruler under a baldicchino throne wearing a hat with two levels (the upper recessed in relation to the lower) sits while a male figure in parti-colored tights to the viewer's left with his back to the reader holds something in his arms; another figure further to the reader's left is partially visible.
Rajna: piuue? piude? piuie? B: cu[n] estre puisent plu. The final strokes of Rajna's handwritten copy are not clear.
MS: fustue?

Illumination follows. Rajna: "Figura. "La e più bella d'ussai fin qui trovata è doppia con una sola scena / a destra il palazzo con due torri, dall'usero si vede nel portony Ugo/ benedire le vivande della tavola a cui siede il pilgri_ a sinistra/ si vede in alto un diavolo che vola colla tavola, e sotto fuori dall'uscio/ Ugo e altri che guardon su con atti di meraviglia _ una donna sta / meraviglij o piuttosto atterita a una finestra _ c'è espressione
Rajna seems to have "lafu" crossed out before the final "lafu," whether correcting his own error or one of the MS is unclear.
Rajna: per has a dot above the "r" but this appears to be an imperfection of the paper.
Here Graf transcribes 5 lines. Rajna: "lo @te" crossed out after "Quando."
MS: grand; Rajna: grand; there is a final something below the line: "o"? B: brand da galons, which makes much more sense.

Nil temere uxori de servis crede querenti :/ Semper enim mulier quem coniux diligit odit./ Catonis Disticha, I, 8 (Éd. E. Baehrens, Poetae latini minores, III, Leipzig, Teubner, 1881). / « Ne crois pas à la légère une épouse qui se plaint de tes esclaves, car une femme déteste toujours celui que son mari apprécie ».
After "lasa", scratched out "le".
Rajna: cħ (in the margin) ᵱocho (chy) non li feze; Rajna note: "scritt. orig/ tutto correz." B: A pués qu'il non li a feit. My emendation for sense.
Rajna: si, "s" written over "l."

MS: aldare. The second letter is an odd combination, a long stroke with a small cross at the "t" level that curves slightly to the right, but not enough to be an "s"; there is not a separated dot so Rajna's "i" does not seem likely.
Illumination follows: Ugon standing by box? bed? with black figure flat. (Rajna: "Ug s'arma al letto della moglie addormenty.")
cobia = "commiato"; cf. B, congieç.
Rajna: choro. MS reading is clear, however, there is no "h".
Graf transcribes five lines beginning here.
Graf, p. 103.
Graf: m[i]o, emendation.
Graf omits ll. 1185-1187; Rajna includes them.
Rajna omits this line initially, then inserts in the right margin.
Rajna note, "corr. da smary; st. / mano" = stesso mano (same hand).
Rajna note, "corr./ da schiary/ st. mano" = stesso mano (same hand).
Rajna note, "corr. da desparty/ st. mano" = stesso mano (same hand).

Rajna note, "corr. da monte / st. m." The structure here is not totally clear: since the third person plural is rare, should this be "montò-ne" for something like "mounted on them," or is it indeed third person plural?

Illumination follows: an encircled area (paddock?) and a house with what seems to be a straw roof; a stands man in the entry and the head and neck of the horse in front of him (to the reader's right) with an armed man riding it, just visible before the burned section. Rajna: "U arriva alla casa del borghese".
Rajna: giesie.
Rajna initially omits this line and adds it afterward in the left margin.
Apostolo: the Pope. Cf. B and other Franco-Italian Apostoille.
The rest of the folio is blank. There is part of the catchword at the bottom of the page, "denan". Rajna also notes the space: "nuovo quad: iniz più grande tracij?/ in lapis"
Rajna seems to have been having difficulties with his pen / ink here; he has a large "D" here at the beginning of this line; or perhaps he is seeking to show the larger "D" as mentioned in his note.

Rajna: ī ? There is no dot on the the letter, so I have transcribed as an "e" though there is no circle around either. Illumination follows: Huon on his knees before the Pope in a very elaborate room with a coffered ceiling. Rajna, "Ug (piviro) ai piedi di un papa gig. Le iniz. sequit a ess transcritte in qto quaderno e manteng spesso la st. grandezza /le segnorò maiuscole."
Graf transcribes 11 lines from here. Note that here the new folio in B (F 10) coincides with Turin's new folio.
Rajna notes, "copto / da una / carta / infra..y". Nothing is now visible before line 1297.
B: nue home si bien non.
The trascriber had not understood here: it's an impossible thing, not not impossible!
MS: dezo nona ho; Rajna: dezo nona homo; B: qu'il non se feit adon, "that this not be done now."
Rajna: homo with the "h" crossed through.
Rajna initially omits this line and inserts later in the left margin.
The end of Rajna's line in undeciphrable here; however, since "sabione" appears four times and there are no other expressions beginning with "sab" this seems most logical.
MS: space between "crosse" and "che": word scraped out? Nothing visible.
Rajna: corr. da sigre?
Rajna initially omits and then inserts in left margin.
Rajna: anchora
Graf, p. 109.
Graf: recevono; Rajna: benedizione .
Graf: si l'eno? .
Line not in Graf.
Graf: sauto.
Various editors cite these final lines, including also Peyron..
Peyron: oldite.

End of Rajna's transcription. The notebook, however, is not ended. It continues through a folio numbered 192. Folio 187 (back and front) is blank. Rajna describes L. I. 14 (Cod. 89) from 188-190; this is a resumé of Octavian. From folio 190V-192V, he speaks of Cod. xxvj =L. II.14 (?) of parchment sec. XIIIo o XIVo 586 folios in 2 columns, with a listing of contents, including Bovo d'Antona.
